fields.description:
While you can use File > New for cloning a repository, some people don't find that intuitive and would prefer an explicit Clone menu item. Worth adding for clarity.

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/78279/how-do-i-clone-a-git-remote-repository/122755
fields.summary: Add dedicated File > Clone... menu item

fields.description:
I would like to prepend my commit message with my initials. We need that in our team because the remote server uses coded-ids instead of proper names in the logs.
So my commit is always:

JelAlt:
- blablabla

Is that something that is possible?

Regards,

Jelle
fields.summary: default commit message

fields.description:
Via Twitter (https://twitter.com/andreasjk/status/289311694365278208): "Any chance we will get tab support in a future version? It gets quite messy with multiple open repos in different windows."

Difficult because the toolbar is context-dependent, but I can see its usefulness having everything self-contained in one repo window. We also should remember people have multiple repo-windows open at once on different desktops and switch between them, so there's a number of obstacles that would need to be discussed on this one. The following would need to be addressed:

1) Tabs would need to be above the toolbar, because the toolbar is context-dependent. This in itself would mean a few problems (tabs being at the very top of the screen so difficult to see perhaps)
2) The ability to have separate windows rather than tabs because people have multiple windows open at once on different desktops. There would need to be an option to switch them on or off, or the user should be able to pull windows apart (like browsers allow you to do "Open in New Window" or "Open in New Tab")
fields.summary: Tab support

fields.description:
After upgrading to 1.5.7 today it seems SourceTree's refreshing has slowed down dramatically. If I change a file and then switch to SourceTree I do not see the change in Working Copy changes. Also, if I push changes from the command line SourceTree will still show the badge on the Push icon indicating the local branch is behind.

After some time it seems to catch up, but it was almost instant before.

Restarting SourceTree seems to bring it up to date, but it still doesn't register new changes going forward.

I switched back to 1.5.6 and it seems to be working fine again.
fields.summary: 1.5.7 seems to be refreshing slowly

fields.description: As title, current workaround is to use the system git
fields.summary: Using embedded git causes SVN -> Git clones to fail

fields.description:
Currently SourceTree differentiates identically named Git projects in its "File > Open Recent" menu. See the attachment illustrating this differentiation. The currently opened windows in the "Window" menu shows open Git repositories named without the differentiation, identifying them ambiguously. See the other attachment illustrating the identically named windows. The impact is I don't know which menu element to click on to view the project, and I switch between them a lot, so I'm guessing, currently.

I expect for SourceTree's existing differentiation code to be reused for the Window menu from the Open Recent menu.

E.g. two projects named "engine", differing by parent folder name "A01" or "A02". You see {"engine-A01", "engine-A02"} in "Open Recent" which is great, and {"engine", "engine"} in "Window" which is ambiguous.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Differentiate identically named Git repositories in Window menu

fields.description:
As reported on twitter: http://twitter.com/StuFFmc/status/286125044327936002

Vertical alignment/sizing could do with tweaking a bit.
fields.summary: Align progress indicator better

fields.description:
Reported on twitter by @boredzo. 

Drag/dropping folders on to the dock icon works fine in the non-Mac App Store version - hg or git repo folders are opened, non-repo folders prompt in the new repo dialog. 

However this doesn't work in the MAS version. The reason is that the plist file (which is different for the Mac App Store version since there are certain things that can't be included in it, such as command line tool installer references and Sparkle data) is missing the required entry under CFBundleDocumentTypes (Document types). It should have 1 entry for folders.
fields.summary: Cannot drag/drop folders onto dock icon in MAS version

fields.description: Because the scope bar relies on constants to figure out which menu is which, when certain menus are hidden (i.e. first parent only) it means the switch statement in the scope bar delegate to determine what's been clicked won't work. To fix this, the constants need to be removed and instead have variables which figure out which menus are which dynamically.
fields.summary: Show/hide 'first parent only' option causes latter scope bar options to stop working

fields.description: I would like to see integration with CompareMerge Pro as a Diff/merge tool. Its inexpensive and works quite well except for the missing commandline support.
fields.summary: Add integration with CompareMerge Pro

fields.description:
I would like to see the "Pull" button default to whatever the current checked-out branch is tracking. Right now, my repository defaults to "Pull from repository: Subversion" and not origin.

Similarly, the Push button defaults to pushing Current Branch to Subversion. If I change the repository to origin, then it has several branches checked by default. I think a better default would be just like the Pull button: only push the current checked-out branch to whatever that branch is tracking.
fields.summary: Change default options for Push and Pull menu bar buttons

fields.description:
I've specified SourceTree to use system git located at {{/usr/local/bin/git}}. I tried also to specify git-flow as {{/usr/local/bin/git-flow}}. But after setting system git-flow, the whole SourceTree will stop working with git command returning lots of errors. Revert to embedded git-flow will fix the problem.

Dig a bit further, it seems both git and git-flow settings save the value in the same key {{gitCustomPath}} in {{~/Library/Preferences/com.torusknot.SourceTreeNotMAS.plist}}. So when both of them are set to use system, both operations will try to use the same binary, and one of them will fail.
fields.summary: Cannot use system git and git-flow at the same time

fields.description:
http://twitter.com/ABWebUS/status/280530391004237825

When a bookmark is pointing at a repository that has been moved or deleted on the file system, we handle that gracefully and display a notification. However, the 'Show in Finder' menu option is still available - it doesn't do anything though.

Ideally, we should disable that menu option in this circumstance.

Update: Actually, he was referring to deleted files. Same thing for those!

TODO:

1. Disable the "Show in Finder" menu item when repo folder has been removed
2. Disable ways to view a repository file if it has been removed.
fields.summary: Disable 'Show In Finder' on missing / moved repository bookmark

fields.description:
http://twitpic.com/bn1ml9

The task window description appears to be too small in the French translation?

Also 'Cloning..' has not been translated it seems.
fields.summary: French task window translation issue

fields.description: If I do a pull and set the revision to pull, hit OK and then do pull again, the revision field is still set to the last rev I pulled. When I do it for pushes, it clears it as expected.
fields.summary: Revision field does not clear after pull

fields.description: As title
fields.summary: Creating remote from the sidebar doesn't expand root 'remotes' node

fields.description: New implementation for a fix will always open up the branch tree regardless. Need a setting to remember the selection and only open it where necessary.
fields.summary: Remember branch hierarchy tree view selection

fields.description: Discussion here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/115974/remember-show-settings-per-project
fields.summary: Consider making saved file filter repo-specific instead of global

fields.description: If you change your setting on the "File Status" tab to "Show Untracked" for example, then switch to a Hg repo, then re-open the Git repo window, the setting will have been forgotten and it will switch back to "Show Pending".
fields.summary: Settings forgotten when viewing other repo types

fields.description:
My ssh key is protected by a passphrase.
I don't want that to be stored anywhere but my head.
Every time I fetch or push with SourceTree and I haven't ssh-add'ed my passphrase on the command line SourceTree prompts me for the passphrase.
However the 'Store Password in Keychain' checkbox is always checked by default.
In my opinion it should be unchecked by default, because the passphrase could end up in the Keychain inadvertently this way.
fields.summary: Uncheck the 'Store Password in Keychain' option by default when prompting for SSH passphrase

fields.description: It would be great if we could type stree -c within a repository (git) and SourceTree would open up ready for committing.
fields.summary: Add support to the command line interface (stree) to open repository in commit mode (-c flag)

fields.description:
Maybe I'm just missing something, but there doesn't seem to be any easy way to find a specific commit in the log/history (or any other) view?

E.g. I am given a commit hash when a particular change was made, and I don't want to check it out but I do want to view the graph around it to see what happened around that time and then maybe create a branch or merge it or cherry pick it or whatever. But I can't find how to do this, if it is even possible?

I try pasting the commit hash (partial or full) in the search view and that doesn't even work, either. But even if it did, that wouldn't be as useful as jumping to it in the log view.

Maybe in the "Jump to" drop down there should be a "commit..." which asks you to paste a commit hash in?
fields.summary: Easily jump to or search for commit hash in log view.

fields.description: When adding a new remote, if you've added one, the last focus box would've been the remote URL. If you add another one immediately afterwards, the default focus is on the URL instead of the remote name.
fields.summary: Adding new remotes default input text box

fields.description:
My suggestion is to add some useful metadata to binary files when shown in the diff window.

More specifically, I would really be interested to see the file sizes, before and after.

Since I've just done a sweep to optimize my images, and am now about to commit the changes, it would be nice to see what the total effect on file size is between the commits.

Other metadata that could be useful in this use case are as described in SRCTREE-1299 as well.
fields.summary: Show file sizes for binary diffs

fields.description:
It would be helpful if SourceTree showed all the files/changes when selecting a commit in the log view. Right now it only shows the first file, and the user has to then select the rest of them to see the "entire commit". So it breaks flow when looking through commits.

For comparison, github shows all of them right away - of course it doesn't support flipping between them as easily.

d
fields.summary: show all files when selecting a commit in log view (similar to github)

fields.description: The commit dialog needs to show that a new branch is being committed, as well as the tree and the changeset list in the main repo view. This way, a commit will visually show that this commit includes a new branch
fields.summary: Commit dialog to have visual cue of new branch

fields.description: Need some way of creating a file, because I wanted to include an extension in my .hgrc file but couldn't unless I unchecked 'use global settings', hit OK,then came back into the screen. I want to use global settings for my user configuration, for example, but just want to use an extension for this repo.
fields.summary: "Edit Config" option in repo settings doesn't do anything at all if default config is used

fields.description:
We have a parent repo that consists of third party git repos as submodules inside a vendor folder. We also have more of our own repos as "library" submodules, and those submodules also have a vendor folder.

Those on the team using command line are able to check out and submodule init in the root folder, and then they get our library submodules and the root repo's third party content, but WITHOUT the library submodules' third party content.

This is a problem because having multiple libraries, e.g. Zend, confuses our intellisense.

As far as I can tell, with SourceTree we can either get all or nothing, and if I manually init it via command line I have to be very careful because the wrong double click can initialize them recursively, ruining that careful work.

Ideally we can get a clear option to better control this behavior, or at least a way to toggle the recursion flag on/off.

I understand this may not be a super common use case, but it does seem to be an actual limitation of SourceTree, as pairing it with the command line accomplishes the desired goal fine. I very much wish I could do all of this within SourceTree, and not have to tiptoe around the Submodules listing there lest it initialize the whole enchiladas.
fields.summary: Repo-level setting to disable --recursive option in all submodule operations

fields.description: All the divider lines between the split views in the application are double width, and look really bad.
fields.summary: Divider borders in the UI are two pixels wide

fields.description: The sheet which shows the current activity when doing any repo action doesn't default to the "Close" button. This would allow you to hit the enter key instead of having to click "Close" especially if you set ST to leave this dialog open once finished.
fields.summary: Focussed button on action sheet should be "Close" once finished

fields.description:
When you resize the repo window so that the log view options 'Hide Merges' and 'First Parent Only' become a drop-down, the purpose of the options is obscured, becoming '(None)' when neither are selected and '(Multiple)' when both are selected. When one is selected, that is displayed in the header.

I think there must be a way to give the header a more friendly label in these cases? If not, maybe we can add one, because otherwise especially '(None)' is hugely confusing and is the default.
fields.summary: Summary display of Hide Merges and First Parent Only in drop-down mode is unintuitive

fields.description:
The method for hiding the First Parent Only option in the scope bar isn't quite working correctly.

# A gap is left in the scope bar when the option is removed
# When you resize the window to the extent that the scope bar options are changed into drop-down options (or back again), the option re-appears
# When first opening the window, if All Branches is the default option the First Parent Only option is still displayed
fields.summary: Visibility of First Parent Only not quite right

fields.description:
After creation of branch in git repo, source tree crash every time when trying to open the project.

-->How was the branch created exactly?
In sourcetree, click branch button, then in popup enter new branch's name ('flash_dev') and then click create branch button. After clicking on create branch button source tree has crashed and trying reopen then it crashes again and again. 

--> git branch -vv output shows:
* flash_dev df41511 [*] flash docs added to ignore
  master    df41511 [origin/master: behind 4] [*] flash docs added to ignore

What is probably happening is that because the "[*]" is used at the start of the commit message, SourceTree thinks it's looking at a remote branch specification. 
They're normally the first thing after the local branch, in square brackets.
fields.summary: Newly created branch causes SourceTree to crash

fields.description: You currently can only remove a remote from the settings in the top-right of ST repo window. You should be able to do this from the context menu in the sidebar so that it's similar to other sections of the sidebar (tags, branches etc.)
fields.summary: "Remove" remote option on context menu in sidebar
Please create ability to jump to Git commit page from the commit description pane

fields.description:
When there's no Internet connection builds fail due to Developer ID certificates on Mountain Lion.

Related: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11712322/error-the-timestamp-service-is-not-available-when-using-codesign-on-mac-os-x
fields.summary: No Internet connection causes builds to fail

fields.description:
Linked Answers Q: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/112557/git-amend-a-commit-do-more-than-change-the-message?page=1

Basically need to be able to do a commit and specify you want to amend the previous commit but also unstage/stage files from the previous commit if you like (as well as hunks). This is done using --soft of the reset command, this way it can be reverted if cancelled.
fields.summary: Add capability to amend latest commit but stage/unstage files (git reset --soft HEAD^)

fields.description:
When working with a git repo, one of the most common tasks I need to do is pull from the remote repo. Currently, in SourceTree, what often happens is:
1. I click the "Pull" button.
2. As the window loads, ST also goes and fetches the remote repo
3. With the "Pull" modal dialog still up, I see the list of commits populate with the remote umerged commits.
4. I click "OK" and ST goes all the way back to the remote repo, and pulls (another fetch and a merge,) failing if it can't fast forward. If I need to fix my commits so that a fast forward works, if I pull again, it again fetches from the remote.

I would like to see those extra fetches done away with. Either have ST not do a remote fetch if I'm about to do a pull. Or, alternatively, de-emphasize 'pull' and instead make ST fetch as normal (that is, on a schedule or if the user presses the button to do so) and have an easy way to say "try to merge up to the latest remote commit I have locally." Right now, if I fetch and need to merge, even if it's a fast forward merge, I have to select my latest local commit, open the merge dialog, select the latest remote, and hit "OK".
fields.summary: A better fetch/pull/merge procedure in git

fields.description: When clicking on the Terminal icon, it would be nice if SourceTree could open a new iTerm window rather than launching a tab in an existing iTerm window.
fields.summary: Ability to open iTerm as window rather than tab
Invalid STASH credentials shows 'lexical error' when listing projects on Welcome screen

fields.description: Besides displaying the image itself, it would be nice to see the image width and height in pixels as well as the image's DPI (if available as part of the image format) in the diff view.
fields.summary: Display image size and dpi in diff view

fields.description: It would be very helpful if you could compare your current working copy to any commit in the graph. Currently it seems you can only diff against branches,  not specific commits.
fields.summary: Diff against current for commits

fields.description:
Using GIT.  Today I did something really stupid and accidentally committed the deletion of a whole directory of important files.  And to make matters worse, the delete was in the same commit as a complicated rework.

The "Reverse" button in the diff window saved the day, and while I probably deserved the penance of clicking Reverse on each of the 500 files, it would be lovely if next time I could shift-select all the files to reverse and just click a reverse function once.

Thanks for SourceTree.  It's a great product.
fields.summary: Reverse diff on multiple files in a commit.
Push sheet "Select All" checkbox stays checked after closing sheet

fields.description:
On my remote Git repository, one user pushed a branch in all upper-case: origin/INTEGRATION. I pushed my local branch to origin/integration. In Source-tree, only origin/integration is visible.

> git ls-remote

shows both branches.

shouldn't SourceTree show all the branches in the repository?

If not, could SourceTree detect branches that only differs by case and handle that situation in a more user friendly way; it could inform the user about the situation (warning that there's a naming collision) and offer an option to rename/delete one of the branches?
fields.summary: If the remote Git repository has two branches that only differ by case, only 1 is displayed in SourceTree

fields.description:
After doing a blame it would be really useful to be able to do a standard "Find" to quickly locate various points of interest in the blamed source code.

Currently you have to scroll to the appropriate line which can be difficult if you don't happen to have the exact line number, but you often know something you could search for.
fields.summary: Support Finding text in the log blame window

fields.description: Adding and committing the attached CSV file shows a wrong diff in the log view. As you can see from the also attached screenshot, only the first line of the diff is being shown as added, and instead of one column in the gutter which displays the line number, there are three columns in the gutter, and the last column in the gutter contains the first character of the line being added.
fields.summary: Adding CSV file shows wrong diff

fields.description:
To Reproduce:

1. At the command line, cd to an existing git repository.
2. Create a new orphan branch (a branch with no parent) by executing 'git checkout --orphan NAME_OF_NEW_BRANCH'.
3. Open this repository in SourceTree, e.g. by typing 'stree .'

Actual behaviour:
SourceTree frequently displays an error dialog with the message: "'git log' failed with code 128: FATAL: bad revision 'HEAD'." These error messages don't go away until you make an initial commit on this orphan branch.

Expected behaviour:
Nothing out of the ordinary.
fields.summary: Orphan git branches cause errors in SourceTree

fields.description:
At least one user has a slight confusion on how subrepositories worked and added one by drag/dropping their local subrepo checkout into the parent, then when adding the subrepo used that same local path for both the source and the relative destination. In their case this caused locking problems in hg, but more generally if they'd tried to share that parent repo with others, the subrepos would not have been available to clone. The source path should almost always be a remote clone (although we allow browsing the file system for people that use it for unusual cases, like local-only setups or file share remotes).

We should add some validation here so that the source path is not allowed to be a subfolder of the parent.

Original issue: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/109288/always-waiting-on-lock-on-subrepository
fields.summary: Add validation on source when creating a subrepo/submodule

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to get either a list of unmerged heads in the log view, or the ability to hide the branch names for those branches that have already been merged.  I'm thinking of functionality similar to git branch -av --no-merged .
fields.summary: Log filter to show only unmerged branches/hide merged branches

fields.description:
I often push to my remote git repository and the push happens so fast I cannot hit the "Show Output" button before the window auto-hides itself.  It would be super useful to somehow be able to view the output after a push/pull for debugging failed push attempts or failed git hooks that are supposed to execute on the remote.

LOVE THIS PROGRAM!!!!!!
fields.summary: View push/pull output after push/pull complete

fields.description: It would be cool to be able to merge branches without first having to switch to the separate branch and then pull the other branch you want in. For instance if I could click merge and then get to choose the branch to merge changes from and then the branch to merge changes into it would be cool
fields.summary: More Advanced Merge

fields.description:
It's generally not useful to take local bookmarks between machines, but it would be useful to be able to recreate the local set up by exporting the bookmarks with their source URLs, gleaned from the remote info of each.

Ideally it would be good to be able to export the bookmarks structure and names, the clone URL (primary remote), and possibly even ancilliary remotes and other repo settings (would probably require a dump of the .git/config / .hg/hgrc). Then when importing you should be able to fire off a bulk clone operation which reconstructs the bookmarks and repo clones on the new machine.
fields.summary: Export / import bookmark structure and clone source info

fields.description:
The default font in the actual interface of SourceTree (not the diff view) has very small font. Despite having 20/20 vision, I find it quite difficult to work with, especially on high-res displays. I've searched through the preferences but could not find a way to increase the size of the GUI font.

Please allow changing the font-size and family to any of the system's available fonts. Thanks.
fields.summary: Allow Changing Font Size in SourceTree Interface

fields.description:
If a character which would be present in the log call is badly encoded, it can stop FoundationKit from decoding the entire 200-line block of log lines as UTF, and subsequently cause issues with other, properly encoded UTF characters elsewhere. 

Typically this is caused by someone committing from another platform using Latin-1 encoding or similar. Eventually the problem passes into history and extended characters start working again for recent log entries, but it can mess up the display for a while.

The problem is that the FoundationKit methods for converting NSData to NSString simply abort the entire conversion when a badly encoded character is encountered. Right now we just fall back on other encodings so we can at least display something, but really what we'd like to do is identify where the decoding failed, decode up to that point, decode the problem character some other way, then decode the rest as UTF. Or, force the interpretation as UTF anyway and leave that one character garbled. I haven't found a way to do either on FoundationKit yet, but since this can cause issues that don't appear on some other tools that use other more tolerant decoders (like Java), it deserves another look. Perhaps there is another third party NSData -> NSString decoder we can use instead.
fields.summary: Improve handling of badly encoded characters

fields.description:
I use SourceTree as full screen application. I find that there are times when I need to use the command line version of git to accomplish my task and it would be handy if there was an embedded terminal. Nothing fancy, just a plan shell console.

I realize there is a terminal toolbar icon, but using that breaks my workflow a little bit because I use SourceTree as full screen and the toolbar icon launches the Terminal app. 

I'm sure you guys have a lot more things on your radar, and this is just a nice to have. Either way, I love SourceTree, thanks for all of your hard work.
fields.summary: Embedded Terminal

fields.description:
Kaleidoscope (http://www.kaleidoscopeapp.com/) is releasing a version 2.0 which is in beta right now. 

I've had reports that SourceTree says it can't find Kaleidoscope when using the v2.

Also, version 2 now supports merging too, so we should add support for it in the merging dialog. May need to detect what version the user is running though.
fields.summary: Support Kaleidoscope v2

fields.description:
When I commit my changes in Git an information (console) window will apear with the information about the commit or push. 
The close button has no focus so I have to use my mouse to close that window.

Is it possible to give it autofocus or let me select it with my keyboard (f.i. tab key)
fields.summary: After commit the 'Close' button has no focus.

fields.description:
SourceTree creates temporary files in $TMPDIR that are not removed when a repository window is closed, or the app exits. This happens under normal usage, apparently during synchronisation.

That directory ought to be cleaned-up when the files are no longer necessary, as under normal operation the OS only does it at a restart (or possibly a re-login). Which is not a frequent event on a workstation class computer.
fields.summary: temporary files remaining behind

fields.description:
One thing I really miss from managing my Git repository in IntelliJ is change lists (http://www.jetbrains.com/idea/webhelp/changelist.html) which are essentially grouped changes.

They are very handy when a developer has several things going on at once (e.g. your core work and some comment cleanup) that they want to keep separate. I find them incredibly useful.

In SourceTree I envision something as simple as "by groups view" that groups the hunks in the working tree files - essentially a one-level tree view. The user can drag between groups like they can for staged/working. There would be an ungrouped group and the ability to add/delete new groups.

Commit would work the same as now, you stage what you want and commit. You would, of course, be able to stage an entire group.
fields.summary: Add support for grouping hunks (eg change lists in IntelliJ)

fields.description:
When closing a hg-flow feature branch/bug fix branch, SourceTree collapses all the separate commits into a single commit, which is the default hg-flow behaviour.

However, there are times when I would prefer to keep all the separate commits, so I have a history of some of the changes I've made.

I know the git-flow default for closing a feature branch is "git merge --no-ff myfeature", which collapses all commits into one. To do the close/merge without collapsing, you can do "git merge myfeature".

How can I close the branch without collapsing in hg-flow ?

How to do it in SourceTree GUI for both hg-flow and git-flow ?

Ideally I would like to be able to cherry pick multiple commits to keep when closing the branch, so these cherry-picked commits will appear in the develop branch for reference.
fields.summary: Hg-flow: How to close feature/bug fix branch and keep all the branch commits as separate commits (ie. don't collapse into single commit) ?

fields.description:
I created a new hg-flow feature branch, did a couple of commits on it, and then selected the first commit and did an Update to operation.

The sidebar ended up showing two feature branches with the same name, and there was no tick icon overlay to the left of the branch name indicating the current branch.

I then did another commit and now there is the tick icon overlay next to the first feature branch. However, I now appear to have two feature branches with the same name.

Is this a bug, or is this expected behaviour ?


The reason I did the above steps was because I created a feature branch and tried out various ways to do something in my code. I forgot to commit, and then decided on the final solution, deleting all the other code. After doing his commit, I realised I wanted a record of those other ways in the commit history, and so used Undo in the text editor to get all the other code, and then commited that. After that commit, I wanted to go back to my original solution, and so did an Update To operation to the first commit. I then had a few smaller changes and committed again. This is how I ended up with the above behaviour.
fields.summary: Sidebar branch section shows two of the same branch after updating to a previous commit on a hg-flow feature branch

fields.description:
While trying to install the standalone command-line tools package designed for the Mac App Store version of SourceTree, I was informed that the package was signed with an expired certificate. The certificate details show that the certificate expired on Nov 6, 2012 - so just a few days ago.
This is the URL of the command-line tool package installer, from the SourceTree help document:
http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/sourcetree/SourceTreeAppStoreCmdLineToolInstaller.pkg
fields.summary: Command-line tool installer package signed with expired certificate for ST from Appstore

fields.description:
The detail text while (for example) pushing to a remote repo is in RED.
Makes me always think something is wrong.
Can this be changed to some other color? (Green, action?)

Picky, yes, but annoying nonetheless (love ST, thanks for keeping it going)
fields.summary: Change status message text color from Red (error) to some other color

fields.description:
Sourcetree is not always able to link file system renames automagically in Mercurial repositories... it would be extremely helpful if a user could highlight two files in a list (one "missing" and another that is "not tracked"), right click, and choose "Rename" and basically perform an "hg rename" operation retroactively (file level rename to original name, then hg rename to new target name).

At the same time, a standard rename option in the GUI would be great for when you just want to right-click on a single file, pick rename, and enter the new name (triggering a typical "hg rename" operation).
fields.summary: We would like to be able to perform "hg rename" operations in the GUI on missing files.

fields.description:
To reproduce:
1. Create a git repository with branches organized in a hierarchical structure, such as AB/button-alignment. SourceTree shows this structure as folders.
2. Check out "develop" in that repository in SourceTree. Make sure you have no other local branches.
3. Check out AB/button-alignment. Look at the left pane. You'll now see the AB folder as expected in your local branch list, and you are actually currently on a branch thats in that folder. However, the folder hasn't been expanded for you, so its hard to tell where you are at all. Notice that none of the branches in the list are now bold (the one thats bold is hidden), so it looks like you are "nowhere" in terms of your repository checkout.

Expected:
When checking out a branch that will be in a newly created folder in the source list, SourceTree should automatically expand that folder, so its clear where you are.
fields.summary: SourceTree should expand the folder when checking out a branch from it

fields.description:
I attached two files showing the issue more specific.

1) unnecessary_horizontal_scrollbar - this shows the files-in-working tree view in the log view. the untracked files are in a subdirectory of a subdirectory of a subdirectory (3 directories). None of the names requires more space than there already is in the view because the with of the view is more than enough. However there still is a horizontal scrollbar

2) toggle_scrollbar - this will only be reproducable on Mountain Lion since this is a new feature. When hovering over a scrollbar it gets bigger so it is easier to use it. Unfortunately, the unnecessary horizontal scrollbar mentioned above now gets into our way. When trying to only select the last entry (index.html in this case), the scrollbar gets bigger. This only happens if I recently scrolled. Meaning that if I wait for some time, the small scrollbar will disappear automatically and I will be able to select the last entry.
fields.summary: Horizontal Scrollbar unnecessary/counter productive

fields.description: If there are local changes it should just change the branch and not prompt.  It should only prompt if there are local changes - then it should say something like "you have local changes.  options: cancel, stash then checkout, throw away changes and checkout"
fields.summary: don't prompt to switch branches if there are no local changes

fields.description:
1) I would like the ability to individually show/hide remotes from the commit browser window.

2) It would also be nice to "just show this remote."


I consider myself an advanced git user, and I often have multiple remotes in projects. Be it, people's forks on bitbucket/github, or a remote I added to pull code from a laptop running `git serve` on the LAN.

Especially when pulling code from from computers on the LAN, I would like to hide the remote. Once I pull code, I usually disable the server. I'd rather SourceTree didn't try to pull from it! But it would be nice to restore the configuration in the future without re-typing hostnames.

Once I pull from a LAN host, the remote's branches become *stale*. The remote might progress forward, but because it isn't running a server anymore, SourceTree never finds out. This is especially distracting, if a "crazy-idea" branch was on the Ad-hoc server.


use case:
1) I'm contributing to an open source project, I want to see all the commits from several contributors. After browsing one remote, I decide the commits aren't useful to me now, so I hide it from view. 

2) I want to see just the origin remote and my local branches.
fields.summary: Hide some—not all—remotes from view

fields.description:
I'd love to be able to copy paste names of branches, stashes, and other items from the sidebar.

Reproduce:

1. Open up a project, and make sidebar visible.
2. Click on a branch in sidebar to highlight.
3. Command-C (copy) while the branch is selected.
4. Go to terminal or other text editor and Command-V (paste).

Expected output:

Paste the name of the branch you had selected and copied.

Observed output:

The clipboard buffer is unaffected by the prior Command-C, so you'll see whatever was last in your clipboard buffer (perhaps nothing).
fields.summary: Copy branch / stash name from sidebar to clipboard

fields.description:
The version tag prefix in hg flow settings seems to become ignored when finishing a release.

What I did:
1. Created a new repository, clicked "hg flow" and set the "Version tag prefix" to "v" -> 2x OK
2. hg flow -> Start new release -> Release version "2.0" => this created the branch "release/2.0" (without "v", but this may be ok)
3. hg flow -> Finish current -> (why can't I change "Tag with this message"?) -> OK

=> The tag, that has been applied to the merged changeset in master (5) is "2.0" instead of "v2.0", so the "version tag prefix" has been ignored the whole process: It wasn't shown in previews, any change messages or branch-names.
fields.summary: hg flow version tag prefix ignored

fields.description: When creating a new branch, it would be convenient for SourceTree to automatically capture the spacebar, and insert an underscore character in its place. This could improve user experience by lowering the amount of "invalid branch name" errors.
fields.summary: when creating a new branch, interpret "spacebar" as an underscore

fields.description:
When browsing a Working Copy in SourceTree, it is extremely annoying to only show the collapsed folders when looking at changes only.
This would be useless when showing the whole repository, but for all filters that show only a small portion of it, it would nice if the tree was expanded by default, to get a quick glimpse of what exactly is changed, and the status of the different files, just looking at the icons, instead of expanding folders one by one.
fields.summary: Make file tree views that show only changes expanded by default

fields.description:
The one git flow command that has a keyboard shortcut associated with it in the menus – "Next Action..." – unfortunately opens a dialog for which keyboard navigation does not function. It seems that a button is highlighted when the dialog opens, but I can't tab away from it. In many cases (due to our company's release workflows) I don't actually want to click that button, but would rather choose another git flow operation from the dropdown list. Unfortunately, I can't seem to tab away from that button and have that list gain keyboard focus.

It would be nice if there was a way to perform my frequent git flow operations without having to move my hands away from the keyboard.
fields.summary: Keyboard navigation disabled in git flow "Next Action..." dialog

fields.description:
1. Either clone a new repository from an external source and select a destination directory which is accessed via a symlink; or add a pre-existing repository accessed via a symlink.  Note that this requires explicitly specifying the path via typing it into the field, if a path is selected by navigating in the file browser GUI, then any symlinks are fully expanded (so this issue does not arise).  To confirm that the repo is registered via a symlink check that the path in the Bookmarks list uses the symlink and has not expanded the path.

2. Open the repository in the 'File Status' view and select the 'Show Pending' view, and make sure that the 'Refresh automatically when files change' option is set in Preferences > General.

3. Externally (e.g. via touch foo) add a file to the repository (or change a file in the repository) now return focus to SourceTree, the modified/added files will *not* appear as changed in the 'Files in working tree' section, now press <command>+<r> and they will.  If the same repository is added (after removing the current bookmark for it) *without* using a symlink when specifying its path then the files will indeed automatically appear marked as changed when SourceTree is given focus.
fields.summary: Auto-refresh of changed files not working for symlinked repositories

fields.description:
copying the .git/HEAD file to the repo root directory (so at the same level as the .git directory instead of within the .git directory) confuses ST display (see attachment). 

ST should be able to find this and make it non-ambiguous
fields.summary: ambiguity between the file called HEAD and HEAD being a commit ref

fields.description:
SourceTree allows you to leave the release branch intact when finishing a release (see the After finishing options), so one would not assume that it is absolutely necessary to delete the release upon finishing (though the default does imply this may be considered best practice).

Indeed this is by design; It's there because git-flow exposes it too (http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/). The default is to delete. But on can also imagine that some people might want to keep the branch around temporarily and delete it themselves at a later time if they choose.

Can SouceTree UI or Help be updated to also specify this?
fields.summary: Git Flow release branch must be deleted before creating an other git flow release branch

fields.description: Attached crash report instead of it being in the description
fields.summary: SourceTree crash by click on commit

fields.description:
Right now you can see the file differences between two points in the history by multi-selecting or right-clicking and selecting 'Diff against current', but you cannot see the commits themselves. It would be useful to be able to filter the log in different ways, such as:
# What commits are in branch A and not branch B? https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/103093/customized-git-log-output?page=1#comment-103444
# What commits will be pushed next?

It might make sense for this feature to be in the Search view as a different option, since depending on the filter the graph might not make any sense.
fields.summary: Support filtering the log / searching between two commit points

fields.description: I have a common scenario where I've selected the push checkbox while making a commit, but the push fails because someone has made changes to the branch upstream (I need to pull). In this scenario, the initial push failure is expected, but I'd like an immediate way to recover from that. I'd prefer an option to automatically pull-then-push when the push checkbox is used from the commit window, or if that's not possible, the failure sheet from the first push should have a button to allow me to tell SourceTree to pull-then-push.
fields.summary: SourceTree should allow automatic (or guided) pull when pushing from the commit window

fields.description:
To reproduce:
1. Open a repo and make some changes.
2. Make some changes elsewhere so you'll have to pull before pushing to the repository.
3. Pull up the commit sheet. Check the "push" button on it to push immediately. Type a message and commit.
4. The commit will succeed, but you'll get an error sheet because the push has failed (you need to pull). Great.
5. Open the commit sheet again. You see the old message there, as if the commit has failed. In reality though, the commit has succeed but the push has failed. This message is no longer relevant since it's been committed to the repository successfully already. I'd expect it to be cleared, just like SourceTree generally clears commit messages on fully successful commits.
fields.summary: Commit message doesn't get cleared when push-on-commit fails

fields.description:
I have a use case as follows:
We have bug tracker at work, and after I commit I need to put the commit hash in the bug tracker for the fix.
I'd like to be able to write a script that can, for example, get that commit and copy it in the right format to the clipboard, based on whats currently in the SourceTree window.
This would require some scripting capabilities:
1. At a first level, would just be great if we could get the names of windows open in SourceTree. This would help me identify the repository currently open in SourceTree, and my own scripting could do the rest.
2. At a second level, would be great if SourceTree could tell me the full path to the currently open window's repository. This would be a better way for me to do (1).
3. Ideally, it would be great if SourceTree could let me pull out the hash of the most recent or currently selected commit directly via AppleScript or another scripting interface.
fields.summary: SourceTree should have scripting support

fields.description:
The ^M character in the git log is causing ST to crash. The issue is that git doesn't interpret it as a carriage return (because it doesn't support OS 9 style), but when ST sees it, because it's using Cocoa, it does interpret it as a line separator. 

In the meantime, the workaround would be only to rewrite that commit and get rid of the character, but you can only do that if the commit is local only (not pushed). If you haven't pushed it, amend can be done like this:

git commit --amend -m "New commit message"

provided it' limited to just that latest commit

Otherwise you'll have to move forward with a git commit a dummy file from command line. Then ST can start again. And it will crash again if you select the version with the git commit log that contain the ^M characters from the ST GUI.
fields.summary: Git commit log with ^M characters causes ST to crash

fields.description: If passwords are let say 50+ characters, it is not possible to login to services such as github ("GitHub: Requires authentication" ) and bitbucket ("Bitbucket API failed") for instance.
fields.summary: SourceTree should handle long passwords

fields.description:
Reporting on behalf of [@typex20|https://twitter.com/typex20/status/263946678560763904]. See [his report machine translated|http://honyaku.yahoofs.jp/url_result?ctw_=sT,eja_en,bF,uaHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZXZlcm5vdGUuY29tL3NoYXJkL3M4MC9zaC84NmFiYjcyMC00NDY2LTQ2NTUtYTM5YS0wNTFjNjZiZjIyOGIvODc2NWI2MTUwNzFhZmU5ZGE3ZjVlOTJkOTdkODM2ZDk=,qfor%3D0] for the screenshot and details. In a nutshell, you can't enter repository name due to the layout error, hence you can't create a repository.  
His original report in Japanese is [here|https://www.evernote.com/shard/s80/sh/86abb720-4466-4655-a39a-051c66bf228b/8765b615071afe9da7f5e92d97d836d9] just for your information.
fields.summary: Can't create a repository on hosting repository due to the layout error

fields.description:
I keep switching branches and getting the error:

error: Your local changes to the following files would be overwritten by checkout:


Granted this is my fault for not stashing or committing my changes prior to switching branches, but instead of throwing an error and making me stash my changes and then go back through the dialog to checkout the branch I wanted, how about offering the user a simple dialog like:


error: Your local changes to the following files would be overwritten by checkout: ...

Would you like to stash these changes and continue with the checkout?



Then I can quickly say yes, checkout the branch I wanted, and then if I want apply the stash to the new branch manually.
fields.summary: Offer to stash changes for the user when a branch change would cause files to be overwritten

fields.description:
Since Bitbucket now supports creating pull requests between branches, pull requests have become a natural fit for a code review step in gitflow/hgflow -type work processes.

Previously, developer would merge a feature branch into development branch directly. Now, developer can create a pull request (from feature to development) instead. Once the code has been reviewed, either developer or reviewer can then execute the merge and close/delete the feature branch.

This works very nicely on the website, but it requires keeping a web browser open all the time. It would be nice if pull request creation would be possible directly in SourceTree, and that it would integrate with the gitflow/hgflow workflow. 

For example, *Flow dialog could have a "Create pull request for Feature/Hotfix" in addition to current "Finish Feature/Hotfix" buttons. That button would then create the pull request between feature/hotfix branch and develop branch.
fields.summary: Provide support for creating pull requests between branches in SourceTree

fields.description:
Please make it easy to push the currently checked out branch and nothing else.  Neither I nor any developer I know pushes more than one branch at a time.  If you read the git mailing list you'll find that even the core git developers are backing away from the "git push pushes every local branch upstream by default" model.

Right now the easiest way to push a single branch is:
1. Check the "select all" checkbox
2. Uncheck it to deselect everything
3. Search out the branch I want to push in the list
4. check its checkbox
5. click OK

This is way too much work for the default workflow.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Easier "Push" for current branch

fields.description: When IU pulled and updated I had a conflict to resolve.  There was an option to resolve using Mine, but the option to resolve using Theirs (the one I needed) was not enabled.
fields.summary: Mercurial option to Resolve Using Theirs is ghosted out.

fields.description: Currently only the stash / shelve name is displayed in the sidebar, and the diff when you click on the entry. It would be useful to also display the branch and base commit on which the stash / shelved changes were made originally.
fields.summary: Add branch name and base commit in stash/shelve diff display

fields.description:
Git and Hg treat rebase conflicts differently; Hg treats it as an unresolved merge conflict (except that parent1 is 'theirs' rather than 'mine'). In git there is only one parent during a rebase conflict, which is 'theirs', and there is no direct way to get the SHA of 'mine'.

This means that the generalised approach to Resolve Using Mine between rebase and merge is not working in the case of a git rebase conflict.

Should change the implementation to be separately implemented in each subsystem instead of just the SHA information being delegated.
fields.summary: Git rebase conflict 'resolve using mine' doesn't work

fields.description:
If I want to add a remote repository to my project and have a typo in there, e.g. a dot (.), I do not get any feedback from SourceTree.

SourceTree will simply close the dialog. When I check again, which remote repositories are in my project, I will not find the misspelled repository I wanted to add, which is correct.

Please provide a user feedback for the dumb users like me, when they want to add a git repository location, which does not make any sense. :-)

Thank you.
fields.summary: Add Remote Repository Settings has no feedback on illegal characters in branch name

fields.description:
The File Contents window doesn't properly display the contents when a staged or committed file is using CR line endings (example of such a file attached to this ticket for your convenience).

- It thinks the entire file is a single line. "1 lines added" in the top summary
- The first line is green/red with the +/- sign in the 3rd column
- The remaining lines have the first character in the 3rd column instead of in the "body" window pane

This only happens with staged/committed files. When previewing a file that is in the working tree, it shows properly.

Also attached is screen shot showing the untracked file (showing proper) and the staged file (showing corrupted) as well as the test text file using CR line endings.
fields.summary: Staged/committed file content preview issue with CR line endings

fields.description:
Tags disappear from the graph view on the right.

I could reproduce the problem. It happens when creating a new tag based on another tag and removing the old tag. 

Steps to reproduce in SourceTree:
1. Create a new git repository
2. Create a file (touch x) and commit that
3. Create a new tag for the working copy parent
4. Create a new tag and enter the previous tag name in "specified commit"
5. Delete the old tag
6. No tags are shown anymore in the graph view

Tags are shown correctly in the "Tags" section on the left. But they are not shown in the graph view to the right. 

Interestingly, it does not happen when creating the new tag in the commandline with "git tag NEW OLD" - but SourceTree copies more info from the old tag to the new one than this command which is good.
fields.summary: Tags Not Shown in Graph

fields.description: Sourcetree has become my preferred client for Git and I want to be able to use it the way I use Mylyn in Eclipse.  Specifically, I want to be able to see all JIRA issues (using whatever filters I select), and then select an issue to be used for my commit message.  I also want to be able to associate specific hunks of a change to an issue since a single file may actually contain changes for different issues.
fields.summary: Add better JIRA integration

fields.description:
Whenever performing a task, the status bar (NSProgressBar) is put into the spinning progress mode, and spins while the task is being done, but when the task finishes, instead of turning solid blue (or white), it remains in 'spin' mode.  This is misleading to those of us who are used to other behavior.

This happens for fetches, pulls, pushes, branches, merges, commits, checkouts -- anything that will drop the sheet from the front window which includes a progress bar.
fields.summary: status bar (NSProgressBar) remains in striped (in progress) mode even when task is finished

fields.description:
Originally raised here: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/100328/sourcetree-bug-in-diff

# Right-click on any local branch that is not checked out and that is not the same as the current branch.
# Choose DIFF against current.  A list of files that are different will be displayed.
# Right-clock on any local branch that is not checked out and that IS the same as the current branch.
# Choose DIFF against current.   

The file list from the previous diff will not be removed and will still show.  Should show no files since there are no differences.
fields.summary: Choosing 'Diff against current' for current branch doesn't clear previous range diff

fields.description: git subtree is a neat way to intregrate source from multiple remotes without messing up where to push which changes etc. Please add support for it in SourcerTree.
fields.summary: Add support for git subtree

fields.description:
It would be great if the working tree/staged panels had a column with # of lines changed like diff --stat shows, and if the view was sortable by this column. Screenshot attached of where it should go

Example of output:
{code}
 app/helpers/publishers_helper.rb                   |   10 +-
 app/models/accounting_adjustment.rb                |    4 +
 app/models/address.rb                              |    9 +
 app/models/address_type.rb                         |    4 +
 app/models/affiliate.rb                            |    8 +-
 app/models/attachment.rb                           |    4 +
 app/models/attachment_item.rb                      |    5 +
 app/models/attachment_static.rb                    |    4 +
 app/models/attachment_unique.rb                    |    4 +
{code}
fields.summary: Add column with # of lines changed per file in working tree/staged views

fields.description:
Trying to push to a remote host (using Git).

After having specified the wrong username (which may have existed on the remote for another user), I had to delete the file hostusernamemap (~/Library/Application Support/SourceTree) in order to get SourceTree to stop asking for the password for that account, and enabling me to correctly specify my real username

Can this be made more user friendly somehow?
fields.summary: Specifying wrong username leads to problems
